div1.ab: Consulate of the United States of America ar Bathurst 1st March 1862
div1.p: Sir, I have delayed forwarding the annual Report of the trade and commerce of the Gamb ia for the last year in anticipation od Mr Consul Uptons return from the states for him to do so but as that Officer has not yer arrived, I will no longer defer during se. Tberewith I have th pleasure to forwar you also the report of Henry Rider Esquire Consular agent for the Sierra Leone district.

The year 1861 has, I am happy to say been a more prosperous one for the trade and commerce of the Gambia than either of the two previous years the yield of the groundnut crops was more abundant and consequently the natives who cultivate them, were enabled to purchase more largely of American and European goods. The increased demand in France for Groundnuts for purposes.
Honorable W.H. Seward Secretary of State for the United States

makes the French merchants and Traders keen competitors with the English in the purchase of these nuts from the natives and finding has the latter gives the preference to many of the English articles of manufature the French have of late introduced the system of trading with the natives for Cash instead of the Barter Trade with good hitherto + exclusively pursued and to so great are extent has this Cash Trade been introduced that it has materially affected the importation of goods and a consequences deficiency in the Colonial Customs Revenue has taken place.

The Colonial Legislature with a view to meet this altered state of Trade has lately passed An Ordinance (which however was not yet been confirmed of Her Majesty) abolishing thr four per cent advalorem duties hitherto paid upon the importantion of any goods into the Colony and have adopted an export duty of one and a half cent per Bashel of 20lbs on Groundnuts and /our each on Hides by this new systen of station the man who trades with Cash will contribute equally towards the Colonial Revenues with the man who trades with goods.
The important differences in the United States has during the last twelve months prmisely affected the importation of American

for do which will observe by Table Not has fallen off nearly one third whilst the Exports remains nearly the same the Produce being bought by Bills or Cash instead of being in Exchange for American Manufacturers.

Pea Nuts no longer arriving in the northern from the southern ports of the Union has created a greater demand for those raused in African the best quality of which is to be had in the Gambia.
I have the honor to be Sr, Your Most Obedient Humble Servant Thomas Rover Acting United States Consul
